summary: This document is a series of internal FBI emails from September-October 2020 discussing and seeking approval for international travel to the UK to interview a key witness in the Epstein/Maxwell investigation. The witness, who was part of Epstein and Maxwell's circle for several years, refused to discuss details over video conference, necessitating an in-person interview.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as a central figure in the investigation for which the witness is being interviewed.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned alongside Epstein as a central figure in the investigation for which the witness is being interviewed.

connections.description: Referred to together as the subjects of the investigation, with the witness being part of their 'circle'.

events.title: Planned FBI/AUSA travel to UK for witness interview
events.description: FBI agents and Assistant U.S. Attorneys from SDNY planned to travel to London to conduct an in-person interview with a key witness in the Epstein/Maxwell case, as the witness was uncomfortable discussing details over video conference.

events.title: Originally planned witness interview trip (cancelled)
events.description: An initial trip to London to interview the witness was planned for March 2020 but was cancelled due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

keyFacts: A key witness in the Epstein/Maxwell investigation, who was part of their social circle for several years, refused to provide detailed information over video conference, insisting on an in-person interview.
The FBI and SDNY AUSAs planned a trip to the UK from October 12-17, 2020, to interview this witness, anticipating she could provide significant information.
The travel request involved detailed cost estimates totaling $6,179 for two people, requiring approval from FBI headquarters and the International Operations Division (IOD).
The correspondence highlights the ongoing, active investigation into Epstein and Maxwell by the FBI's Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking unit and SDNY prosecutors in late 2020.
Multiple FBI personnel are involved in the email chain, but their names are redacted, indicating internal procedural coordination for investigative travel.
